VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 4 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
The facility's 4 CAPs were results of violations on special investigations. The rule
violations and compliance are as follows:
- 2024SIC0001543 dated 7/31/24 (CAP approved 8/28/24) had a repeat
violation for Rule 126(1) Staff Sufficiency due to a staff member not
providing supervision per a youth's safety plan. As a result, the staff
received disciplinary action and had more frequent meetings with their
supervisor to discuss supervision requirements.
- 2025SIC0000112 dated 12/12/24 (CAP approved 1/6/25) had a violation
for Rule 142(1)(e) regarding dispensing medications. This CAP resulted
in disciplinary action for the staff who did not follow proper procedures
for dispensing medications, met with upper management to review the
medication administration policy & signed the policy stating their
understanding.
- 2025SIC0000380 dated 3/11/25 (CAP approved 3/19/25) had a repeat
violation for Rule 142(1)(e) regarding dispensing medications. This
investigation involved a different staff than the #112 investigation. This
staff also received disciplinary action, had to meet with upper
management to review the administration policy and signed the policy.
In addition, nursing reviewed the medication administration protocol as
well as the QuickTip CARF document regarding limiting distractions
when passing medications at staff meetings in March.
- 2025SIC0000408 dated 3/19/25 (CAP approved 3/28/25) had a repeat
violation for Rule 142(1)(e) regarding dispensing medications. This
investigation involved a different staff than the #112 and the #380
investigations. This staff also received disciplinary action, had to meet
with upper management to review the administration policy and signed
the policy. In addition, nursing reviewed the medication administration
protocol as well as the QuickTip CARF document regarding limiting
distractions when passing medications at staff meetings in March.
Financial Overview
The facility's budget and financial audit were reviewed. There were no concerns
noted.
3

PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted staffing has been fairly consistent and they are
continuing to hire new staff. CA reported the biggest barrier to hiring has been
waiting on out of state background checks. CA noted they have had a full and
steady clinical team for a while now, which has been very beneficial for consistency
of care and treatment for youth. CA noted they continue to address issues related
to CAP compliance for violations on special investigations, especially with the
recent repeat violations regarding medication administration.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported the following:
- There have been some recent transitions with supervisors as one APM just left for
a different position and another APM resigned. Their losses have caused some
friction, but staff are recovering, and things are getting better. They've hired two
new APMs and they're fitting in well to their roles. They're in a good spot staffing-
wise and don't feel there is a lot of turnover with staff.
- It appears there's been a culture shift recently regarding staff, and staff are truly
meeting youth where they're at and approaching things with more grace than they
have in the past. Younger staff have grown through coaching and evaluations, and
there is more consistency in treatment as well as approaches with youth. They're
continuing to work on making sure they're up to date on eCare documentation and
making that a priority right after the safety and well-being of youth. If difficult
conversations need to happen between staff, they're happening in a healthy way,
and there's great conflict resolution skills being used. There's less conflict, gossip &
cliques amongst staff, which is helping the shift in culture. Credit should be given to
CA and Manager of Program Operations for leading from the top down. Staff and
supervisors have access to CA and Manager of Program Operations frequently,
and it's very helpful in providing the support staff and supervisors require.
- Activities with youth are going really well. They try to get the youth out as much as
they can. During breaks and weekends, they have approximately 2-3 options to
choose from. On school days, they do science activities, cooking groups, outside
time at parks, etc. Feedback is taken really well by staff and management.
Management is very supportive. Training is sufficient for their roles.
- Staff feel supported, and they have a really good crew. There is great
communication and feedback between peers and management. Upper
management has been putting forth a lot of effort to be present and supportive. The
4

only room for improvement would be the difference in quality for shadow shift
training for new employees. The person doing shadow shift training may not know
ahead of time they're doing the training due to picking up a shift or something else
happening, so there is sometimes a lack of preparedness which causes a lack of
consistency in training. However, if staff are following the paperwork adequately,
there shouldn't be a problem.
Youth reported they do a lot of fun things and enjoy the outings staff take them on.
Youth reported staff are nice, supportive, and helpful. Youth reported the food is
good and they get enough food. Youth reported they feel safe at the facility and
have staff they can speak with if they need something. Youth reported no concerns
with the facility or staff.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility was completed on 4/4/25 and there were no safety
concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
